data.title: Hang Seng Tech Index Pares Gains, Last Up 2.9% at 4876.38
Market Chatter: Airbus Explores Possible European Space Venture with Thales, Leonardo
data.description:
French aerospace company Airbus reportedly mandated Goldman Sachs Group to advise on the formation of a space and satellite business with Thales and Leonardo (LDO.MI) that can compete with Elon Musk's SpaceX.

France-based defense and technology group Thales is in talks with advisers, while Italian aerospace company Leonardo is working with Bank of America for the plan termed Project Bromo, Bloomberg News reported Tuesday, citing people familiar with the matter.

Talks related to the creation of the European space venture are at an exploratory stage and no service offerings are determined yet. The three-way venture will also be subject to antitrust considerations, the report noted.

Airbus, Goldman Sachs, Leonardo and Thales did not immediately respond to requests for comments from MT Newswires.

(Market Chatter news is derived from conversations with market professionals globally. This information is believed to be from reliable sources but may include rumor and speculation. Accuracy is not guaranteed.)

data.title: Egypt's non-oil private sector posts growth in January, PMI shows
data.description:
Egypt's non-oil private sector expanded in January, marking its best performance in over four years and its first growth since August as output and sales volumes increased, a business survey showed on Tuesday.

S&P Global's headline Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rose to 50.7 in January from 48.1 in December, signalling a renewed improvement in the sector's health at the start of 2025.

A PMI reading above 50.0 indicates growth, while below that level points to a contraction.

January's figure was the highest since November 2020, driven by a pick-up in domestic market conditions and a softening of cost pressures, which helped boost sales. However, uncertainty over the sustainability of this upturn weighed on business expectations and hiring.

"The ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas likely added confidence to markets in January," said David Owen, Senior Economist at S&P Global Market Intelligence. "That said, business expectations for the next 12 months remain subdued, showing that firms are still uncertain about economic stability over the longer term."

The output sub-index climbed to 51.1 from 47.1 in December, while the new orders index rose to 51.3 from 46.4.

Despite the positive start to the year, firms remained cautious about future activity, with expectations slipping to a near historic low. Employment levels stabilised after two months of job cuts, but hiring was limited.

The sub-index for expected future output fell to 52.8 from 53.8 in December.

Cost pressures eased to an eight-month low, with input prices rising at a slower pace. This allowed firms to raise output prices only slightly, marking the softest increase in four-and-a-half years.

While the construction sector saw a decrease in purchase costs, other sectors experienced slower inflation than in December.

data.title: EMEA Morning Briefing: Stock Futures Rise After U.S. Delays Mexico, Canada Tariffs
data.description:
MARKET WRAPS

Watch For:

Trading updates from UBS, BNP Paribas, Intesa Sanpaolo, Diageo, Infineon Technologies, Vodafone Group, Publicis

Opening Call:

European and U.S. stock futures gained alongside advances by Asian benchmarks following a delay to U.S. tariffs on Canada and Mexico. The dollar fell; Treasury yields edged higher; while oil and gold futures fell.

Equities:

Stock futures were higher early Tuesday, while markets across Asia staged a relief rally as risk sentiment improved after President Trump and the leaders of Mexico and Canada reached a deal to put tariffs on hold for a month.

Meanwhile, China hopes to negotiate over the 10% extra being imposed on its exports to the U.S. Beijing is readying an opening bid to try to head off greater tariff increases and technology restrictions.

The on-again, off-again tariffs briefly hit the market on Monday, before fear evaporated. What it shows: Investors are convinced he will use tariffs to extract concessions on other issues, rather than, as he keeps saying, to raise money and force companies to relocate to America.

Forex:

The U.S. dollar is likely to maintain its safe-haven status in 1H, DBS's Philip Wee said. Trade uncertainties loom despite the U.S. delaying tariffs on Canada and Mexico, the senior forex strategist said, adding there's potential volatility in markets from Trump's unpredictability.

Meanwhile, Trump has given notice that the European Union is next in line for U.S. tariffs, Wee noted. Also, there was no 30-day reprieve for the additional 10% tariff on Chinese imports, with markets awaiting responses from Chinese President Xi, Wee said.

Bonds:

The corporate-debt market has so far shrugged off Trump's tariff announcements. After a brief disruption in debt issuance, companies of varying credit quality are expected to resume debt sales Tuesday, bankers and analysts say.

"After monitoring how things are going, it feels like the tone is a lot better," said Meghan Robson, head of U.S. credit strategy for BNP Paribas.

"As long as we're on a Fed pause, we think credit can do well," said Robson. "When you get rate hikes, we'd start to be more concerned about fundamentals, but we think we're still a ways away from that."

Energy:

Volatility remains high in crude oil markets as the threat of U.S. tariffs continues to loom, ANZ said. Trump's calls for OPEC to lower prices were meanwhile ignored, as the group decided not to make any changes to its existing oil production plans, ANZ added. The OPEC+ alliance is likely awaiting more clarity on other Trump policies, ANZ said.

Metals:

Despite the U.S. deal to delay tariffs on Canada and Mexico, "uncertainty over trade and tariffs continues to buoy gold prices," ING said.

The bank said the precious metal had risen to a new all-time high after Trump's initial imposition of tariffs as investors sought safe havens. ING added that dollar strength has offset some strength in gold overnight.

-

Copper gained in Asian trade. Uncertainty over tariffs is likely to keep volatility high in commodity markets, ANZ said. Base metals had been under pressure recently due to demand concerns stemming from the impending trade war, it said.

TODAY'S TOP HEADLINES

U.S. Pauses Tariffs on Mexico, Canada. China Levies Are Still Happening-for Now.

President Donald Trump is pausing plans for 25% tariffs on goods from Mexico and Canada after separate meetings with the leaders of both nations.

Canada Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said in a social media post on Monday afternoon that the threatened tariffs had been paused for "at least" 30 days.

Bitcoin rebounds after Trump pauses Mexico, Canada tariffs. Here's why the crypto reacts to tariffs.

Bitcoin rebounded to above $100,000 by Monday evening, after President Donald Trump said he would pause imposing tariffs on Mexico and Canada.

Bitcoin BTCUSD, the largest cryptocurrency by market capitalization, experienced a weekend selloff, falling to as low as $91,229 early Monday, its lowest level since Jan. 13, according to Dow Jones Market Data.

A U.S.-EU Trade War Would Threaten World's Richest Economic Relationship

BRUSSELS-European leaders, bracing for a fight with President Trump over the world's most valuable trading relationship, said they are ready to strike back but prefer cooperation.

Trump over the weekend announced punishing tariffs on Canada and Mexico and made clear that U.S. allies across the Atlantic were high on his target list. He later agreed to pause tariffs on Canada and Mexico for one month.

Tariffs Will Be Especially Bad for Europe. What They Mean for European Stocks.

With friendly trade partners like these, who needs enemies? That is what European countries must be thinking as President Donald Trump prepares to target them with his next round of taxes on imported goods.

After unveiling 25% levies on goods from Canada and Mexico, as well as an additional 10% tax on Chinese products, Trump said Sunday that he would soon move on to Europe.

Apple escaped tariffs last time. This time, it may have to raise prices.

Apple Inc. was one of the luckier consumer-electronics companies when it got exemptions from the tariffs imposed by the first Trump administration on many goods made in China.

But this time, it might not be quite as fortunate.

Nvidia's stock falls as these two questions dog investors

Nvidia Corp.'s stock fell Monday as investors weighed the potential for tariffs to impact chip companies and continued to assess the fallout from DeepSeek.

Shares of Nvidia NVDA slid 2.8% to rank among the worst performers in the PHLX Semiconductor Index SOX. The stock pared losses after President Donald Trump said he had agreed to pause the Mexico tariffs for a month. A similar deal to delay tariffs on Canada came later in the day. China still faces 10% tariffs starting at midnight.

Write to singaporeeditors@dowjones.com

Expected Major Events for Tuesday

01:01/IRL: Jan Ireland Manufacturing PMI

07:00/ROM: Dec PPI

08:00/SPN: Jan Unemployment

16:00/DEN: Jan Foreign Exchange & Liquidity

All times in GMT. Powered by Onclusive and Dow Jones.

Write to us at newsletters@dowjones.com

We offer an enhanced version of this briefing that is optimized for viewing on mobile devices and sent directly to your email inbox. If you would like to sign up, please go to https://newsplus.wsj.com/subscriptions.

This article is a text version of a Wall Street Journal newsletter published earlier today.

India's Divi's Lab gains again on Q3 print; analysts flag good execution, key risk
data.description:
** Divi's Laboratories rises ~5% in second session of gains post Q3 results

** Co's custom synthesis segment grows 45% y/y in Q3

** BOB Capital upgrades to "hold" from "sell", citing co's effective opportunity utilisation in the fast growing segment

** Jefferies retains "hold" despite custom synthesis improving product mix and profit

** Says co needs to overcome high rev concentration of key heart failure drug the patent for which will expire in 2026

** Co working on glucose stabilising hormone GLP-1 manufacturing process to diversify

** Systematix Equities says DIVI seeing interest in GLPs from several MNCs; has strong position due to backward integration

** Stock up 66% YTD

data.title: Tropicana Repurchases More Shares
data.description:
Tropicana bought back 420,000 shares for 490,603 ringgit on Monday, according to a same-day Malaysian bourse disclosure.

The shares were repurchased by the real estate firm at between 1.160 ringgit and 1.170 apiece, the filing said.

data.title: India Shares Trade at Near 4-Week High
data.description:
India's equities advanced 523 points, or 0.7%, to 77,684, while the Nifty 50 was above 23,500 in Tuesday morning trade, tracking a rise in Asian peers as concerns about a potential trade war eased after U.S. President Donald Trump delayed tariffs on Canada and Mexico for a month.

The BSE Sensex hit its highest level in nearly four weeks, halting losses from the previous session, mainly supported by gains in metals, oil & gas, banking, and tech sectors.

Additionally, mid-cap and small-cap stocks gained, rising over 1% each.

The RBI interest rate decision, which will be announced later this week, also lifted sentiment, with the market expecting the central bank to cut rates by 25 bps amid a slowdown in GDP growth.

Among the early top performers were Tata Motors (2.6%), Larsen & Toubro (2.2%), ICICI Bank (1.9%), Axis Bank (1.9%), and IndusInd Bank (1.8%).

By contrast, Power Grid fell 1.3% after posting a 4% YoY fall in its consolidated net profit for the December 2024 quarter.

data.title: India's Welspun Enterprises slides on Q3 profit decline
data.description:
** Shares of Welspun Enterprises fall 6.1% to 564.5 rupees

** Stock heads for biggest daily pct decline in over three months

** The infrastructure developer's Q3 consol profit fell 3.6% to 770.5 mln rupees ($8.9 mln)

** Co's rev rose 22.7% to 8.67 bln rupees while expense jumped ~30% to 8.02 bln rupees

** WELS moved below its 50-day and 100-day simple moving avgs after the results

** More than 1.6 mln shares traded, 4.4x its 30-day moving avg

** Stock sees most active day in over eight months

** WELS rose 88.3% in 2024, gaining for fifth straight year

($1 = 87.0275 Indian rupees)

data.title: Japan 10-Year Yield Hits Near 14-Year High
data.description:
Japan’s 10-year government bond yield climbed to around 1.27% on Tuesday, reaching its highest levels in nearly 14 years as the suspension of US tariffs on Mexico and Canada reduced safe-haven demand for JGBs.

Late on Monday, U.S. President Donald Trump agreed to “immediately pause” the planned tariffs on Mexico and Canada for a month following successful negotiations with their leaders.

Additionally, Japan’s Finance Ministry was scheduled to auction off 2.6 trillion yen of 10-year JGBs on Tuesday, putting further upward pressure on domestic yields.

Investors are also looking ahead to Wednesday’s release of Japan’s latest wage figures, which could influence the outlook for Bank of Japan monetary policy.

The BOJ raised interest rates again in January and has signaled its readiness to hike rates further if economic and price trends align with forecasts.

* Details on the BTr's website www.treasury.gov.ph

($1 = 58.29 Philippine pesos)

AMA Group Signs Deal to Assemble, Repair Electric Buses
data.description:
AMA Group entered into a strategic service agreement with Gemilang International to assemble and repair electric buses in Australia, according to a Tuesday Australian bourse filing.

AMA will be a partner of Gemilang, a Hong Kong-listed, Malaysia-based bus manufacturer, to complete any required local content assembly of electric buses that the latter proposed importing into Australia.

AMA will also be the preferred repair partner for the buses.

The firm's shares rose 2% in recent trading on Tuesday.

data.title: China's Sihuan Pharmaceutical falls on wider annual loss outlook
data.description:
** Shares of Sihuan Pharmaceutical Holdings Group Ltd fall 3.4% to HK$0.56, extending losses for a second session

** Stock posts its biggest intraday pct drop since Jan 22

** Sihuan expects to record revenue of not less than 1.80 bln yuan ($248.25 mln) and a net loss of not more than 600 mln yuan for 2024, as generic drug business declines amid centralized procurement policy in the mainland and high R&D expenses

** This compares with a revenue of 1.86 bln yuan and a net loss of 54 mln yuan in 2023

** Hang Seng Commerce & Industry Index (.HSNC) rises 1.7%, healthcare index (.HSCIH) gains 0.5% and Hang Seng Index adds 1%

** Stock climbed 1.5% last year

($1 = 7.2507 Chinese yuan)

data.title: Hong Kong Shares Pare Gains After China Announces Tariffs on Some U.S. Goods
US 10-Year Yield Firms as Trump Delays Tariffs
data.description:
The yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury note stabilized around 4.56% on Tuesday, recovering from multi-week lows hit in the previous session as the postponement of planned U.S. tariffs on key trading partners reduced safe-haven demand for Treasuries.

Late on Monday, President Donald Trump agreed to “immediately pause” tariffs on Mexico and Canada for a month following successful negotiations with their respective leaders.

Markets are also growing more optimistic that the U.S. and China could reach a deal to avert the 10% tariffs on Chinese imports set to take effect later today.

However, investors remain cautious, as the potential for tariffs could reignite inflation and limit the Federal Reserve's ability to cut interest rates further.

Traders are also awaiting Friday's nonfarm payrolls report, which will provide further insight into the health of the labor market.

data.title: Sports Toto Repurchases Shares
data.description:
Sports Toto bought back 350,000 shares on Monday for about 547,569 ringgit, according to a same-day Malaysian bourse disclosure.

The shares were repurchased between 1.550 ringgit and 1.570 ringgit apiece, the betting company said.

data.title: News Highlights: Top Financial Services News of the Day - Tuesday at 12 AM ET
data.description:
Trump Signs Order to Create U.S. Sovereign-Wealth Fund

The president said the fund could be used to help keep TikTok operating.

Vanguard Is Delivering Its Biggest Fee Cut Ever. New CEO Salim Ramji Explains Why.

The asset manager says the move at 87 funds will save investors $350 million this year.

Bitcoin rebounds after Trump pauses Mexico, Canada tariffs. Here's why the crypto reacts to tariffs.

Bitcoin rebounded to above $100,000 Monday evening, after President Donald Trump said he would pause imposing tariffs on Mexico and Canada, respectively.

Bessent Takes Helm of Consumer Finance Watchdog, Orders Halt to Work

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent is ordering a freeze to work at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, after being named its acting director by President Trump

Inflation will slow this year, allowing the Fed to cut rates further, says former St. Louis Fed chief

Former St. Louis Federal President James Bullard said that inflation will slow markedly this year, allowing the central bank to continue to lower interest rates.

Private Credit Executives Grapple With Price Hurdles, Rising Competition

Industry leaders point to persistent disagreements on asset prices and swelling ranks of competitors for deals.

It's Write-Down Season, and Some Companies Look Due for Asset Adjustments

Warner Bros. Discovery, CVS and Kraft Heinz all have intangible-asset values that appear out of whack.

Julius Baer Shares Fall After Targeting Hundreds of Job Cuts

The wealth manager's shares fell after it said it envisions cutting around 400 positions, extending its cost-saving program.

Financial Services Roundup: Market Talk

Find insight on gold prices, ETFs, Julius Baer, the Malaysian banking sector and more in the latest Market Talks covering Financial Services.

Wall Street Is Nervous About Scott Bessent's Borrowing Plans

The new Treasury secretary has criticized a borrowing strategy that helped calm markets.

data.title: News Highlights: Top Energy News of the Day - Tuesday at 12 AM ET
data.description:
Oil Rises as Trump's Tariffs Raise Supply Fears

Prices jumped on concerns that U.S. tariffs against its major trade partners could disrupt supplies and raise prices at the pump.

Exxon Enters the Electricity Business, Takes a Swipe at Nuclear

Exxon says it can compete with nuclear, because the gas power plants it intends to build would capture carbon emissions.

U.S. Frackers and Saudi Officials Tell Trump They Won't Drill More

The president says lower prices could solve a range of problems, but finds early resistance in the oil market.

Exxon, Chevron Yearly Profits Down as Investor Payouts Hit Fresh Highs

Annual profits fell, but the oil giants made record distributions to shareholders as production rose to historic levels in key regions.

Energy & Utilities Roundup: Market Talk

Read about tariffs on Canadian oil, natural gas prices, Galp Energia and more in the latest Market Talks covering Energy and Utilities.

Orsted Replaces CEO as Wind Industry Faces Challenges

The company said it is parting ways with Mads Nipper as it grapples with supply-chain bottlenecks, high financing costs and President Trump's opposition to wind power.

Tariffs Won't Sink Canadian Oil Companies

The U.S. has become reliant on their crude, and Canada has ways to limit any financial hit.

Shell Keeps $3.5 Billion Buyback Amid Earnings Miss

The oil-and-gas company's adjusted earnings fell more than expected, weighed by lower oil prices and refining margins.

U.S. Crude Oil Stockpiles Rise for First Time in 10 Weeks

U.S. crude oil inventories increased for the first time in 10 weeks, beating analyst's expectations, as exports fell and refineries lowered their capacity use.

Here's how much gas could cost you if Trump's threatened tariffs go through

President Trump has threatened to place 25% tariffs on Canada and Mexico as soon as this Saturday, potentially disrupting the relatively stable prices drivers have been paying for gasoline during a seasonally slow period for fuel demand.

data.title: Hang Seng Index Pares Gains, Last Up 1.1% at 20450.82
Global Commodities Roundup: Market Talk
data.description:
The latest Market Talks covering Commodities. Published exclusively on Dow Jones Newswires throughout the day.

0313 GMT - Palm oil prices fall in early Asian trading, tracking weakness in soybean oil on the Chicago Board of Trade, says David Ng, a trader at Kuala Lumpur-based Iceberg X. However, the price weakness won't persist, he adds, citing expectations for weak palm oil output. CPO production for Jan. 1-31 is estimated to have fallen 15% on month, according to Malaysia's Southern Peninsular Palm Oil Millers Association. Ng pegs CPO support at 4,250 ringgit/ton and resistance at 4,400 ringgit/ton. The Bursa Malaysia Derivatives contract for April delivery is 43 ringgit lower at 4,324 ringgit/ton. (yingxian.wong@wsj.com)

0151 GMT - Copper rises in early Asian trade. Uncertainty over U.S. tariffs is likely to keep volatility high in commodity markets, ANZ Research analysts say in a note. Base metals had been under pressure recently due to demand concerns stemming from the impending trade war, they say. However, concerns have eased after Mexican President Sheinbaum says U.S. tariffs on her country's exports will be delayed for a month, they say. Trump has also agreed to delay tariffs on Canada, and focus now turns to China. The three-month LME copper contract is 0.4% higher at $9,139.00/ton.(amanda.lee@wsj.com)

0047 GMT - Gold edges higher in early Asian trade. The precious metal hit a new record high this week as investors continue to place their money in safe-haven assets due to uncertainties around rising trade tensions, ANZ Research team writes in a note. There are also fears that precious metals may be caught up in the trade war, the analysts add. Spot gold is 0.1% higher at $2,815.83/oz. (kimberley.kao@wsj.com)

2258 GMT - The proposed 25% tariff on Canadian shipments to the U.S. could cost Rayonier Advanced Materials up to $3.5 million per month while in place, the company said. "Even with these potential tariffs at currently announced levels, the company expects to cover all fixed charges, including maintenance capital and interest expenses," it said. Last year, about 11% of the company's total revenues were generated from Canadian Paperboard exports to the U.S., it added. The company also said it sees 2025 Cellulose Specialties average sales prices increasing mid-single-digit percentage from 2024 levels. (stephen.nakrosis@wsj.com)

2253 GMT - If President Donald Trumps ends up implementing 25% tariff hikes to Canada and Mexico goods, the consumption-related companies that would be impacted the most would be in the produce goods and alcohol spaces, BofA Securities analyst Bryan Spillane tells WSJ. "This would drive produce prices higher, especially for fruits," Spillane says, adding that 40% of the U.S. produce comes from Mexico. Other companies in the grocery space that would get hit by tariffs and higher prices are Mondelez International and WK Kellogg, given that they don't produce essential food and would see their volumes go down, Spillane says. Mondelez makes about half of its Oreos in Mexico, and Kellogg recently closed two U.S. plants and expanded an existing facility in Ontario. (sabela.ojea@wsj.com; @sabelaojeaguix)

2201 GMT - Aeris Resources held less cash at the end of 2Q than expected by Ord Minnett, which retains a hold call on the stock as it balances long-term value with a stretched balance sheet. Aeris reported A$26 million in cash at end-December, some A$4 million less than projected by Ord Minnett and despite a lower capital spend. Aeris experienced operational challenges at its Tritton copper mine, with output some 27% below Ord Minnett's forecast and costs around 27% higher. "The Tritton issues appear to have been somewhat rectified as FY 2025 guidance is unchanged with improved grades/tons set to come from Bugderygar, Avoca Tank and Murrawombie," says Ord Minnett, referring to other Aeris-owned pits. (david.winning@wsj.com; @dwinningWSJ)

2149 GMT - Packaging company Amcor's newest bull says organic growth is key to unlocking long-term value for shareholders. Jefferies, which raises Amcor to buy from hold, points out that Amcor's volume growth has been anemic since it bought Bemis some years ago. "We estimate cumulative volumes have declined 5%, or 1% per annum since FY 2019, raising concerns around the outlook for plastic packaging and valuation multiple investors are willing to pay," analyst Ramoun Lazar says. Amcor recently agreed to buy Berry, which has a similarly weak track record. Amcor expects deal savings to drive growth in new business areas. "We are not yet convinced (consensus also skeptical) with Jefferies's long-term volume forecasts circa 0-1% per annum," Lazar says. (david.winning@wsj.com; @dwinningWSJ)

2011 GMT - After briefly posting a recovery in the wake of news that the U.S. and Mexico had reached an agreement to stave off trading tariffs for another month, lean hogs succumbed to the pressure that was seen earlier in the session — sending the contract down by its daily limit of 4 cents a pound to 86.35 cents a pound, a 4.4% fall. Higher slaughter rates are one factor pressuring hogs, says Terry Reilly of Marex, but what's also hitting hog futures is reports of labor shortages at meat-processing plants, due to fears surrounding ICE raids in several major U.S. cities. Live cattle futures finish down 1.1% to $2.00125 a pound. (kirk.maltais@wsj.com)

1859 GMT - A 25% tariff on imports from Mexico could be a real headwind for aluminum-can maker Ball, Jefferies analysts say in a research note. For starters, tariffs would drive aluminum prices higher, though the analysts note that Ball could circumvent this cost as it's contractually able to pass it to customers. "The bigger risk is demand destruction, with consumers already dealing with a significant amount of inflation," they write. Ball additionally manufactures beer cans for Constellation Brands in Mexico, as the brewers' Modelo, Corona and Pacifico beers must be made in the country to be considered authentic. Shares of Constellation Brands and Ball fall 2.3% and 0.4%, respectively. (connor.hart@wsj.com)

1841 GMT - Front-month gold finished up 0.8% to $2,833.90 a troy ounce, setting a new record-high as tariffs dominate the conversation in U.S. markets. The uncertainty that surrounds tariff plans appears to be driving investors toward gold as a safe-haven asset, with traders speculating that physical metal prices have room to travel higher. "With supply chain constraints mounting, both gold and silver prices are on the rise, and physical metal premiums could soon follow," says Alex Ebkarian of Allegiance Gold. Ebkarian adds that investments and countries are both showing signs of accumulating gold reserves. SPDR Gold is up 0.6%. (kirk.maltais@wsj.com)

1829 GMT - Grain futures on the CBOT are rising with fund traders opting to cover short positions as the future of Trump's trade initiatives remains uncertain. "CBOT grain prices are following each headline related to U.S. trade," says AgResource in a note. The "fluidity" of the ongoing negotiations has fund traders looking to cut risk, says the firm, and President Trump's comments on tariffs are not helping. "Trump's view is that the U.S. and the world must rebalance trade and manufacturing, which will pose the biggest risk to new trade tariff fears," says AgResource. Most-active corn, in which fund traders hold a net long position of over 350,000 contracts as of Jan. 28., is up 1.3%.(kirk.maltais@wsj.com)

1747 GMT - CBOT grain futures may be taking cues from news other than Trump's decision to hold off on Mexico tariffs for a month. "I really think today's rally runs deeper than tariffs," says Karl Setzer of Consus Ag Consulting. "There is too much uncertainty in the tariff talk right now to try and pick a side to be on." What's giving grains a boost today instead is weather issues for Argentinian crops, Setzer says. "Ratings continue to drop on Argentine crops as are production estimates," he says. "Weather turned drier this morning, taking much of the rain out of Argentine outlooks." Most-active corn is up 1.4%, soybeans rise 1.6%, and wheat climbs 1.7%. (kirk.maltais@wsj.com)

data.title: KKR Raises Tender-Offer Price for Fuji Soft
data.description:
By Kosaku Narioka

KKR said Tuesday that it decided to raise its tender-offer price for Japanese software company Fuji Soft to 9,850 yen a share from 9,451 yen.

The U.S. investment company will also extend the tender-offer period through Feb. 19, it said in a regulatory filing.

KKR has been competing with rival Bain Capital to acquire Fuji Soft.

Write to Kosaku Narioka at kosaku.narioka@wsj.com

data.title: Bilendi Completes Purchase of Data Collection Company Netquest
data.description:
Bilendi said Monday it completed the acquisition of data collection company Netquest from NielsenIQ - GfK.

The French market research-focused technology, data and artificial intelligence company integrated Netquest into its accounts on Feb. 1.

Netquest owns and operates data panels in Spain, Portugal and 19 countries in Latin America. It also has six panels in Europe and the US.

data.title: Kasikornbank Set to Gain From Likely Higher Fee Income, Lower Cost-to-Income Ratio — Market Talk
data.description: Kasikornbank stands to gain from likely higher fee income and lower cost-to-income ratio, CGS International's Weerapat Wonk-Urai says in a research report, as the brokerage maintains the stock's add rating. The bank recently unveiled 2025 targets such as achieving net fee income growth of mid-to-high single digit versus 6.7% growth in 2024 and attaining cost-to-income ratio at low-to-mid 40s versus 44.1% ratio in 2024. Also, the Thailand bank will focus on growing retail loans that are primarily housing and credit-card loans in the high-income segment, the analyst notes. However, the brokerage trims the stock's target price to THB187.00 from THB188.00 to reflect a lower 2025 book-value forecast. (ronnie.harui@wsj.com)

data.title: Cardano (ADA) at a Crossroads: Could Bears Take Control Again?
data.description:
Cardano price started a fresh decline below the $0.9250 zone. ADA is now correcting losses and struggling to clear the $0.80 resistance.

  • ADA price started a fresh decline from the $0.9250 zone.
  • The price is trading below $0.850 and the 100-hourly simple moving average.
  • There is a key bearish trend line forming with resistance at $0.8050 on the hourly chart of the ADA/USD pair (data source from Kraken).
  • The pair could start another decline if it trades below the $0.7650 support zone.

Cardano Price Faces Resistance

After struggling to stay above the $0.950 level, Cardano started a fresh decline like Bitcoin and Ethereum. ADA declined below the $0.90 and $0.850 support levels.

There was a clear move below the $0.60 support zone. A low was formed at $0.5105 and the price recently started a decent upward move. The price cleared the $0.60 and $0.70 resistance levels. The bulls pumped the price above the 50% Fib retracement level of the downward move from the $0.9828 swing high to the $0.5105 low.

However, the bears are now active near the $0.80 zone. There is also a key bearish trend line forming with resistance at $0.8050 on the hourly chart of the ADA/USD pair.

Cardano price is now trading below $0.80 and the 100-hourly simple moving average. On the upside, the price might face resistance near the $0.80 zone and the 61.8% Fib retracement level of the downward move from the $0.9828 swing high to the $0.5105 low.

The first resistance is near $0.820. The next key resistance might be $0.850. If there is a close above the $0.850 resistance, the price could start a strong rally. In the stated case, the price could rise toward the $0.9250 region. Any more gains might call for a move toward $1.00 in the near term.

Another Decline in ADA?

If Cardano’s price fails to climb above the $0.80 resistance level, it could start another decline. Immediate support on the downside is near the $0.7650 level.

The next major support is near the $0.7230 level. A downside break below the $0.7230 level could open the doors for a test of $0.6880. The next major support is near the $0.6250 level where the bulls might emerge.

Technical Indicators

Hourly MACD – The MACD for ADA/USD is losing momentum in the bullish zone.

Hourly RSI (Relative Strength Index) – The RSI for ADA/USD is now above the 50 level.

Major Support Levels – $0.7650 and $0.7230.

Major Resistance Levels – $0.8000 and $0.8200.
